Seville

Visualising Rinconete and Cortadillo's world using Spatial Humanities techniques

Bust of Cervantes on Calle Francisco Bruna, near where he was imprisoned.

Modern-day Seville is remarkably similar to seventeenth-century Seville.

Cervantes knew the city very well: he worked there for a period as a tax collector, and was even imprisoned due to 'irregularities' in his accounts. The prison where he was incarcerated is located on what is now one of Seville's busiest shopping streets, Calle Sierpes. The city has erected a bust of Cervantes in the street behind the prison, in commemoration of its most famous prisoner.

Cervantes' familiarity with the city is manifest throughout "Rinconete y Cortadillo": the city gates that he mentions, such as the Postigo del Carbón or the Puerta del Arenal, no longer exist in the same way. However, all of the squares he mentions, such as the Plazas del Salvador, de la Pescadería, and de la Alfalfa, remain bustling social hubs of the city. He also mentions Calle Feria, which remains one of Seville's primary streets for socialising, full of cafés, bars, bakeries, bazaars, alongside the 'mercadillo de los Jueves' - the longest-running market in the city.

A quotation from Cervantes' masterpiece "Don Quijote", in which he exalts 'La Giralda' - the tower of Seville's cathedral. This plaque was commissioned by the City Council of Seville on the 400th anniversary of the publication of "Don Quijote". It is located in the Plaza del Triunfo, beside La Giralda.

A Semana Santa procession drawing huge crowds at the Arco de la Macarena. Beside the arch is the church of La Macarena which has the largest and most famous brotherhood in the city.

Members of the brotherhoods wear traditional dress for the processions.

Still an important feature of modern-day life in Seville are the institutions known as "brotherhoods". The statistics vary, but there are roughly one hundred different brotherhoods, or hermandades, in the city. The biggest and most renowned are: la Hermandad de la Macarena, la Hermandad de la Esperanza de Triana, and la Hermandad de Gran Poder.

The brotherhoods are always affiliated with a particular church, and their most prominent role comes during Semana Santa, when they parade the relics of their church through the streets. However, beyond religion, the brotherhoods also provide a social group and social community for the city's inhabitants (each brotherhood will usually contain a bar). Within "Rinconete y Cortadillo", Cervantes examines, satirically, this commingling of the divine and the secular within life in Seville.

The map below demonstrates that Cervantes' Seville is very similar to modern-day Seville, with the implication that his satire is as pointed and as relevant today as it was in the 17th century. Click the pins to read about the places mentioned in the story and what role they now play.
